2 CORRECTIONS: 1. the big one- plants have 2 organs! the shoot and roots. leaves, flowers, tubers, and others are modified stems (Yes even the flower, I've spoken to my professor with a PHD in Plant biology and my professor with a PHD in Horticulture) roots have meristems as well as shoot meristems; known by most as the Shoot Apical Meristem (SAM) and Root Apical Meristem (RAM). I'm from a botany class, so maybe I'm biased, but if we're gonna teach the kids all the complex organ systems of animals then we better teach them the 2 simple organs of plants. other than that, good work, and never stop making mistakes and improving. B- for getting some stuff right though.

this "immature white man" as you call him (why you need to bring race into the equation is beyond me) makes Biology easy to understand and relatable to not only the youth, but to all those who are not advanced in biological terms yet. I would rather that biology be taught like this in schools, so students can understand what they are learning,  than just forcing them to repeat the same words they do not understand in an effort to memorize the work. This teaching style also makes the subject interesting so students are more likely to do self-research on related topics that they do not yet understand. Unlike xylem (which is composed primarily of dead cells), the phloem is composed of still-living cells that transport sap. The sap is a water-based solution, but rich in sugars made by photosynthesis. These sugars are transported to non-photosynthetic parts of the plant, such as the roots, or into storage structures, such as tubers or bulbs

Nick Spears 1. Describe how water travels from the to cell to the leaf.  Map the way. Water is transported into the roots and enters the xylem. Cohesion and Adhesion cause the water to move through the xylem. It then goes from the xylem in to the mesophyll cells and evaporates through the stomata.  2. How is ground tissue different in the root/stem the the leaf? The ground tissues does not has chloroplast cells/mesophyll cells and does not preform photosynthesis.  3. Describe how the stomata opens and closes. The stomata open due to the guard cells expanding and contracting. The cells expand because of water/turgur pressure. When more pressure is present the cells expand and when there is less pressure they contract and let the stomata open.

+Rc Blaze I assume you included that "not" by accident because it makes your sentence nonsensical. Anyway, it is fully proven. With overwhelming evidence in fact.
Ghost7856 I am a practical type of guy but there is literally no evidence or fossils to prove evolution. All are theories and assumptions

***** Assumption tested and examined time and time again by the very people who make them as well as others who mutually compare their results with them. They're not 100% reliable, but still a lot more so than any other source you will find. At any rate, arbitrarily jumping at the first chance you get to spit apologetics in favor of the creationists is one of the last things I'd ever dub practical-minded.

+Ghost7856 Even if tested time and time again, evolution always ends up in a downfall. Since these people cannot prove there theories about evolution to be true, they change their evidences and experiments a bit to gain attention and say to those people that "evolution is true" which in turn would make evolution in itself an assumption because it is made up of theories that are said to be true yet without a thorough evidence.
***** Uh, yeah, right. I don't think you've researched this topic very well...

+Ghost7856 A basic problem facing evolutionist is finding some means or mechanism that might produce the changes of plant and animal forms, or kinds, required by the doctrine of evolution but no satisfactory mechanism has yet been found.

***** Of course they have, it's the very basis of the whole thing. Errors in DNA replication when a species reproduces are extremely rare, but they do happen. Those changed traits are then passed off to the next offspring, and if those traits are favorable to interacting with the local environment, the new species will stick around. Thus, over millions of years, the face of various ecosystems is modified.
+Ghost7856 An organism without a "link" proves evolution is false.

***** Nope. Absence of evidence is not proof of absence, much less when there is so much actual evidence from other sources. Basic reasoning principle.  Also, don't think I didn't catch you changing your argument right there.

+Rc Blaze This is the exact same point you just made, which I already debunked in a counter-argument that once again you didn't even bother to address. I didn't want to have to namedrop this little game of yours, but... stop moving the goalposts. As for those so-called "make-believe" evolutionary steps, some are certified through tested fossils, while the rest are what we call, in the scientific jargon, a hypothesis. Heavily subject to modification, but still infinitely more trustworthy than blanket statements which people would just prefer to be the truth.

heggyheggy1 Well the apoplastic pathway is the pathway in which water passes through the cortex of the root via the gaps in between each of the cells and also through the cell wall, whilst the symplastic pathway works by osmosis between the cell membranes of adjacent cells in the cortex as cells nearer to the epidermis receive the most water. However it is important to remember that at the xylem the casparian strip of the cells forces water traveling via the apoplast to be forced into the cell raising the pressure potential and forcing water in to the xylem. This is also aided via the active transport of minerals into the xylem which help lower the water potential of the xylem.

I have to help you out here and tell you that is really wrong. Firstly, insects are animals.  Secondly, there are 6 kingdoms, as follows: Animalia (animals), Plantae (plants), Fungi (mushrooms, yeast, mold, etc.), Archaebacteria and Eubacteria (two different kingdoms of bacteria, with Archaebacteria tending to live in more extreme environments), and protista (includes algae, kelp, etc.).  Second of all, of the animals you're talking about, they're grouped like so: Mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish, and insects.  However, these are NOT kingdoms.  They're some of the many classes of animals that exist.  Hope that helps.
***** They are not kingdoms. They are divisions within the plant kingdom.

No, there are are 3 domains: archaea, bacteria and eukarya. Archaea and bacteria are single celled prokaryotes (no nucleus). Eukarya (nucleus) include 4 kingdoms: animalia, plantae, fungi and protista. Protista are single celled eukaryotes (nucleus). Archaea and bacteria are also divided into kingdoms. The kingdoms are divided into phylum, class, order, family, genus and species. There are also sub, infra and or super versions of some of them.

It's funny how our language is a melange of others and how certain languages infuse particular sections of our society. Like the way French words are used for so many things relating to cooking. The word "herbs", for instance, comes from the French herbes, pronounced 'erbs' because that's how French is- hard h's are hard to come by. While Americans have Anglicized the spelling to the English 'herbs' they've retained the French pronunciation, so our sous chefs put "erbs" in their mise en place.

Some amount of vocal change is important.  Monotone voices are obviously bad, and I don't want him to remove all the vocal changes.   The problem is that there are severe swings in tone and volume in almost every sentence.  Instead of highlighting important concepts or drawing our attention to themes, it is exhausting to listen to.  When every sentence screams "LISTEN TO ME!", the whole thing becomes fuzzy and difficult to remember.  Overuse of good speaking techniques is bad technique.
